conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph for object B.
The graph shows the velocity (v) on the y-axis and time (t) on the x-axis. Object B's velocity changes over time, as indicated by the curve labeled 'B'.

Acceleration (a) is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. Mathematically, it is given by: a = dv/dt. On a velocity-time graph, the slope of the tangent at any point gives the instantaneous acceleration at that point.

premise: The slope of the tangent at any point on a velocity-time graph gives the instantaneous acceleration.
conclusion: At t = 0, the velocity of object B is positive and increasing. The slope of the curve at t = 0 is positive, indicating positive acceleration.

premise: The slope of the tangent at any point on a velocity-time graph gives the instantaneous acceleration.
conclusion: As t increases from 0 to t1, the velocity of object B decreases initially, then increases again. The slope of the curve becomes negative at some point between 0 and t1, indicating negative acceleration. After reaching a minimum velocity, the slope becomes positive again, indicating positive acceleration.

premise: The slope of the tangent at any point on a velocity-time graph gives the instantaneous acceleration.
conclusion: At t = t2, the velocity of object B is positive and increasing. The slope of the curve at t = t2 is positive, indicating positive acceleration.

premise: From previous analysis of the slope of the curve.
conclusion: From t = 0 to t1, the acceleration of object B changes from positive to negative and back to positive. From t = t1 to t2, the acceleration remains positive.

premise: From previous analysis of the slope of the curve.
conclusion: Therefore, the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2 is: Initially positive, then negative, and finally positive again.
